Damei wanbao also published in March and April 1938 a serialized translation of a Japanese novella, Ikiteiru heitai (Soldiers alive), by Ishikawa Tatsuzo, which dealt with the behavior of Japanese soldiers in China. The novella was published in Japan in the March 1938 issue of Chuo koron (Central review) but was suppressed by the Japanese police because of its explicit coverage of Japanese atrocities in China

note: The Chinese title was Nu pantu, in English, Girl Rebel (n.p.: Minguang shuju, 1940). In 1943 a translation of the first part of her life story appeared as Autobiography of a Chinese Girl: A Genuine Autobiography,
title: Nubing zizhuan (Taipei [Taibei]: Dongda tushu youxian gongsi, 1980); Xie Bingying, A Woman Soldier’s Own Story: The Autobiography of Xie Bingying

Actually this was not the first of her biographical works to appear in English. The writer Lin Yutang had published a translation of her newspaper columns in English in 1930 in Letters of a Chinese Amazon and War-Time Essays
Lin later wrote an introduction of a 1940 English version of her life entitled Girl Rebel: The Autobiography of Hsieh Ping-ying with Extracts from Her New War Diaries
A combined Chinese and English version with facing pages in the two languages was also undertaken as Lin Yutang’s direction
